Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: F: Statistical Theory and Methods Beyond the Dimensionality Barrier

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
With recent advances in technology, it is now possible to measure and record significant numbers of features on a single individual. The volume, velocity, and variety, the "3Vs", of Big Data pose significant challenges for modeling and analysis of these massive datasets. For example, to understand cancer at the genetic level, researchers need to detect rare and weak signals from thousands, or even millions, of candidate genetic markers obtained from a limited number of subjects. Existing methods typically assume that the number of subjects is very large, an assumption often violated in practice. The main goal of this project is to develop efficient methods for extremely large-dimensional, small sample size data. The methodological advances will be extremely valuable in addressing Big Data challenges in different areas such as medical research, bioinformatics, financial analysis, and astronomic image analysis. Efficient software packages and algorithms to implement the proposed methods will be developed and made publicly available.

The key innovative idea motivating this research is viewing a high-dimensional problem from a novel packing perspective, which allows the number of variables, p, to be arbitrarily large and the number of observations, n, to be finite. The proposed research will systematically investigate three fundamental problems under this "finite n, arbitrarily large p" paradigm: (1) asymptotic theory of spurious correlations, (2) fast detection of low-rank correlation structures, and (3) detection boundary and optimal testing procedures for detecting rare and weak signals. This research will transform the current asymptotic framework, transitioning from the regimes of "large n, small p" and "large n, larger p" to the regime of "finite n, arbitrarily large p".

POR.DRECONTENT:
Big Data brings new, exciting, and challenging opportunities to data scientists. To statisticians, one of the crucial challenges is to overcome the dimensionality barrier, which concerns the limitations of current statistical theory and methods that depend on the asymptotic relationship between p, the number of variables and n, the number of observations. Existing assumptions on this relationship often make statistical methods either not applicable or not efficient in Big Data analysis. To surpass this barrier, the PIs propose a novel inference framework by viewing high-dimensional statistical inference from a packing perspective, which allows the number of variables to be arbitrarily large and the number of observations to be finite. In the funded three years, the PI has published 8 papers and 1 book chapter on the proposed collaborative research. The PI has also got one patent granted based on results from the proposed collaborative project.

Intellectual merits: The novel packing perspectives in this project have brought in ideas to the development of theory and methodologies for Big Data. The PI has achieved the goal of deep understanding of the general form of dependence in Big Data. A novel nonparametric framework for dependence detection was proposed, efficient and powerful algorithms to detect dependency were developed, and interesting scientific results were discovered. The new tools will also be transformative to other problems entangled by the dimensionality barrier.

Broader impacts: The project has benefited the society in many ways. The results from the collaborative project have provided theory, algorithms, and applications to many areas of science including astronomy, biology, genetics and medicine. The PI has trained 8 PhD students (5 female) and 5 MS and undergraduate students (3 female) in related projects. The PI has developed one special topic course for PhD students based on results from the project. The PI has also made impacts through media coverage by writing an article and being interviewed for another article on his research related to scientific reproducibility.
